Browse the source code of tvm/3rdparty/dlpack/include/dlpack/dlpack.h

1/*!
2 * Copyright (c) 2017 by Contributors
3 * \file dlpack.h
4 * \brief The common header of DLPack.
5 */
6#ifndef DLPACK_DLPACK_H_
7#define DLPACK_DLPACK_H_
8
9#ifdef __cplusplus
10#define DLPACK_EXTERN_C extern "C"
11#else
12#define DLPACK_EXTERN_C
13#endif
14
15/*! \brief The current version of dlpack */
16#define DLPACK_VERSION 050
17
18/*! \brief DLPACK_DLL prefix for windows */
19#ifdef _WIN32
20#ifdef DLPACK_EXPORTS
21#define DLPACK_DLL __declspec(dllexport)
22#else
23#define DLPACK_DLL __declspec(dllimport)
24#endif
25#else
26#define DLPACK_DLL
27#endif
28
29#include <stdint.h>
30#include <stddef.h>
31
32#ifdef __cplusplus
33extern "C" {
34#endif
35/*!
36 * \brief The device type in DLDevice.
37 */
38typedef enum {
39 /*! \brief CPU device */
40 kDLCPU = 1,
41 /*! \brief CUDA GPU device */
42 kDLCUDA = 2,
43 /*!
44 * \brief Pinned CUDA CPU memory by cudaMallocHost
45 */
46 kDLCUDAHost = 3,
47 /*! \brief OpenCL devices. */
48 kDLOpenCL = 4,
49 /*! \brief Vulkan buffer for next generation graphics. */
50 kDLVulkan = 7,
51 /*! \brief Metal for Apple GPU. */
52 kDLMetal = 8,
53 /*! \brief Verilog simulator buffer */
54 kDLVPI = 9,
55 /*! \brief ROCm GPUs for AMD GPUs */
56 kDLROCM = 10,
57 /*!
58 * \brief Reserved extension device type,
59 * used for quickly test extension device
60 * The semantics can differ depending on the implementation.
61 */
62 kDLExtDev = 12,
63} DLDeviceType;
64
65/*!
66 * \brief A Device for Tensor and operator.
67 */
68typedef struct {
69 /*! \brief The device type used in the device. */
70 DLDeviceType device_type;
71 /*! \brief The device index */
72 int device_id;
73} DLDevice;
74
75/*!
76 * \brief The type code options DLDataType.
77 */
78typedef enum {
79 /*! \brief signed integer */
80 kDLInt = 0U,
81 /*! \brief unsigned integer */
82 kDLUInt = 1U,
83 /*! \brief IEEE floating point */
84 kDLFloat = 2U,
85 /*!
86 * \brief Opaque handle type, reserved for testing purposes.
87 * Frameworks need to agree on the handle data type for the exchange to be well-defined.
88 */
89 kDLOpaqueHandle = 3U,
90 /*! \brief bfloat16 */
91 kDLBfloat = 4U,
92 /*!
93 * \brief complex number
94 * (C/C++/Python layout: compact struct per complex number)
95 */
96 kDLComplex = 5U,
97} DLDataTypeCode;
98
99/*!
100 * \brief The data type the tensor can hold.
101 *
102 * Examples
103 * - float: type_code = 2, bits = 32, lanes=1
104 * - float4(vectorized 4 float): type_code = 2, bits = 32, lanes=4
105 * - int8: type_code = 0, bits = 8, lanes=1
106 * - std::complex<float>: type_code = 5, bits = 64, lanes = 1
107 */
108typedef struct {
109 /*!
110 * \brief Type code of base types.
111 * We keep it uint8_t instead of DLDataTypeCode for minimal memory
112 * footprint, but the value should be one of DLDataTypeCode enum values.
113 * */
114 uint8_t code;
115 /*!
116 * \brief Number of bits, common choices are 8, 16, 32.
117 */
118 uint8_t bits;
119 /*! \brief Number of lanes in the type, used for vector types. */
120 uint16_t lanes;
121} DLDataType;
122
123/*!
124 * \brief Plain C Tensor object, does not manage memory.
125 */
126typedef struct {
127 /*!
128 * \brief The opaque data pointer points to the allocated data. This will be
129 * CUDA device pointer or cl_mem handle in OpenCL. This pointer is always
130 * aligned to 256 bytes as in CUDA.
131 *
132 * For given DLTensor, the size of memory required to store the contents of
133 * data is calculated as follows:
134 *
135 * \code{.c}
136 * static inline size_t GetDataSize(const DLTensor* t) {
137 * size_t size = 1;
138 * for (tvm_index_t i = 0; i < t->ndim; ++i) {
139 * size *= t->shape[i];
140 * }
141 * size *= (t->dtype.bits * t->dtype.lanes + 7) / 8;
142 * return size;
143 * }
144 * \endcode
145 */
146 void* data;
147 /*! \brief The device of the tensor */
148 DLDevice device;
149 /*! \brief Number of dimensions */
150 int ndim;
151 /*! \brief The data type of the pointer*/
152 DLDataType dtype;
153 /*! \brief The shape of the tensor */
154 int64_t* shape;
155 /*!
156 * \brief strides of the tensor (in number of elements, not bytes)
157 * can be NULL, indicating tensor is compact and row-majored.
158 */
159 int64_t* strides;
160 /*! \brief The offset in bytes to the beginning pointer to data */
161 uint64_t byte_offset;
162} DLTensor;
163
164/*!
165 * \brief C Tensor object, manage memory of DLTensor. This data structure is
166 * intended to facilitate the borrowing of DLTensor by another framework. It is
167 * not meant to transfer the tensor. When the borrowing framework doesn't need
168 * the tensor, it should call the deleter to notify the host that the resource
169 * is no longer needed.
170 */
171typedef struct DLManagedTensor {
172 /*! \brief DLTensor which is being memory managed */
173 DLTensor dl_tensor;
174 /*! \brief the context of the original host framework of DLManagedTensor in
175 * which DLManagedTensor is used in the framework. It can also be NULL.
176 */
177 void * manager_ctx;
178 /*! \brief Destructor signature void (*)(void*) - this should be called
179 * to destruct manager_ctx which holds the DLManagedTensor. It can be NULL
180 * if there is no way for the caller to provide a reasonable destructor.
181 * The destructors deletes the argument self as well.
182 */
183 void (*deleter)(struct DLManagedTensor * self);
184} DLManagedTensor;
185#ifdef __cplusplus
186} // DLPACK_EXTERN_C
187#endif
188#endif // DLPACK_DLPACK_H_
189
